paragraphs.text: With respect to “thinking about if there’s a way to draw/ visualize our thought processes so that they’re easier to share and talk about”. You might find either the Rational Manager (1965) or the New Rational Manager (2013) of interest. Based on the research of Charles Kepner and Benjamin Tregoe, the books outline the fundamental critical thinking…

ac87449a2b1d.title: Humble suggestion, sensei: Under each conundrum is says “so only notice…”, which newbie passersby…

paragraphs.text: Humble suggestion, sensei: Under each conundrum is says “so only notice…”, which newbie passersby could construe as “So you should only notice,” when it means “So *we* only notice…” Perhaps a later version might tuck “we” into each of those great subheads?
paragraphs.name: d2c9

a675be7d7cbe.title: Hi Buster, your post led me onto “The Art of Thinking Clearly: Better Thinking, Better Decisions”…

paragraphs.text: Hi Buster, your post led me onto “The Art of Thinking Clearly: Better Thinking, Better Decisions” (2013) by Rolf Dobelli. Have you read it? It explores a number of our cognitive biases. Fascinating.
paragraphs.name: 398e

eb6cb86f7611.title: Under #1 Only notice… you should include “frightening things, people, events”.

paragraphs.text: Under #1 Only notice… you should include “frightening things, people, events”. The role of anxiety and fear in how we allocate attention is very well documented by research. It helps explain why we can be convinced that a threat of terrorism justifies biased policies when the actual threat is quite minimal compared to other common risks that might be addressed by policies.
paragraphs.name: bc50

433d0f3da51c.title: I’m wondering if conundrum is the right descriptor?

paragraphs.text: I’m wondering if conundrum is the right descriptor? It seems that the four categories are a logical grouping of phenomena. Cognitive biases are blind spots that expose laypeople and experts to poor decisions.

9ff2c664d91c.title: An interesting question is what cognitive load is required to alter or overturn a cognitive bias?

paragraphs.text: An interesting question is what cognitive load is required to alter or overturn a cognitive bias? My hunch tells me that its a heavy cognitive load.
paragraphs.name: 11b3

paragraphs.text: When ever I changed a bias. It was because there was a more powerful and opposing force that changed my perspective. Maybe I was shown great kindness by someone whom I did not…
